ref.mixed-citation: Heilbrun's statements: "I had to admit that science fiction was, for me, a foreign land with an unknown language and mysterious manners. I don't scorn science fiction, any more than I scorn Afghanistan; I'm just one of those who stay at home and mumble about the problems at hand. ... I think we must imagine, not a fantastic world, but how we might speak and act differently in this one. . . . But that language [the language of other fic- tions, other possibilities, and other language in patriarchal language], those fictions must, at least for me, be learned the hard way: in the world where we live. . . . These [the fea- tures of feminist Utopias] are, indeed, longings from many female hearts, including mine. But I live here, where I must find the language to incarnate these things: whether through weakness of intellect or paucity of imagination, I am not content, nor even able, to dream them" (117-19).
